Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Synthesis of Bulk Nanostructured Materials from Semiconductor Quantum Dots

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program grant provides funding to investigate new manufacturing approaches for the fabrication of bulk-scale materials with precisely controlled structure at the nanometer length scale. While nanostructured materials have been intensively investigated from the theoretical and thermal transport points of view, limitations in their processing science have impeded their commercial use. This project aims at overcoming these limitations. Advanced gas-phase techniques will be used to synthesize nanopowders with precisely controlled properties. Ultrafine particles with arbitrary size, size distribution, composition and surface chemistry will be produced and then sintered to yield bulk samples with tunable structural details. The precise control of the nanoparticle properties will translate into the realization of bulk nanostructured samples with an unprecedented degree of freedom in the design of their nanostructure.

The characterization of bulk samples with arbitrarily designed nanostructure will advance the scientific understanding of transport of heat and charge carriers in such systems. A precise description of the role of grain size distribution, porosity and local structure of grain boundaries on transport properties will be achieved. This knowledge will be transferrable to other material systems and valuable to the scientific community. Moreover, the project specifically focuses on earth-abundant materials and on synthesis and processing techniques that are scalable to high production rates, thus representing a step towards the large-scale utilization of materials with good thermal-to-electrical, and vice versa, energy conversion efficiency. This is critical for applications such as waste heat recovery, solid state cooling, and in general, for achieving a more effective utilization of our energy resources. Finally, students from local high schools, college students from underrepresented minorities and veterans from the US military who are continuing their educations will be directly involved in these research activities to enhance their education in the strategically important areas of materials, manufacturing and energy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This CAREER award has advanced the synthesis and processing science of materials that are relevant for energy-related applications. In particular, this award has supported research in the use of low-temperature plasmas in nanomaterial synthesis. Low-temperature plasmas are the work-horse of the semiconductor industry, and their processing capabilities have been crucially important in enabling the information technology revolution. The PI has investigated their use for the production of novel nanomaterials for applications in energy conversion. Overall, the outcomes of this project can be divided into two categories.

In the first one, silicon-based nanomaterials have been used as additives to enhance the functionality of energy conversion and storage devices. For instance, the addition of silicon carbide inclusions into silicon-based thermoelectric devices allow improving their overall efficiency via an energy-selective charge scattering mechanism. This enhances the Seebeck coefficient of the bulk material, i.e. improves the electronic response of the structure when a temperature gradient is imposed. In another example, the synthesis and careful surface modification of silicon particles allows integrating them into current lithium-ion battery architectures, providing an immediate boost in capacity without the need of any change to their current manufacturing schemes.

In the second category, low-temperature plasmas have been used to realize novel materials with interesting optical properties. For instance, these processes allow realizing plasmonic particles composed of titanium and zirconium nitride. These have properties comparable to those of precious metals such as gold and silver, while being thermally resistant, abundant, and considerably advantageous from a cost point of view. Finally, the surface chemistry of plasma-produced silicon quantum dots can be modified to enable new and under-explored optical properties, such as optical upconversion mediated by the annihilation of triplet states into higher energy singlet excitation. Figure 1 shows a colloidal dispersion of these quantum dots as it is being excited with a green laser. As a consequence, the quantum dots emit blue light, i.e. photons with energies higher than the ones used to excite these nanoparticles.

Overall, this body of work suggests that the processing capability of non-equilibrium systems, such as low-temperature plasmas, can enable unique functionalities in materials. From a fundamental scientific point of view, this study has provided significant insights into the properties of these system. From an applied point of view, this study has confirmed that a plasma-based approach is compatible with the processing of sustainable and economically viable materials. Finally, support from NSF via this project has been crucial for the PI?s career development. This project has provided support to a total of four Ph.D. students and several undergraduate researchers, many of whom from groups that are underrepresented in STEM disciplines. This award has also supported high school interns during the summer break. The vast majority of these interns have then continued to pursue a career in engineering.
